pullRequest.body:
Prove the vertical line test for monoid homomorphisms/isomorphisms.

Let `f : G → H × I` be a homomorphism to a product of monoids. Assume that `f` is surjective on the
first factor and that the image of `f` intersects every "vertical line" `{(h, i) | i : I}` at most
once. Then the image of `f` is the graph of some monoid homomorphism `f' : H → I`.

Furthermore, if `f` is also surjective on the second factor and its image intersects every
"horizontal line" `{(h, i) | h : H}` at most once, then `f'` is actually an isomorphism
`f' : H ≃ I`.


---

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.

What's the motivation for considering homomorphisms from an arbitrary `G`, rather than just inclusions of subgroups? The statement actually only depends on the image of `f` in `H \times I`, not on `G` and `f`.

FWIW, a submonoid version of your first lemma might look like
```lean
lemma Submonoid.eq_graph (G : Submonoid (H × I)) (hf₁ : Surjective (Prod.fst ∘ G.subtype))
    (hf : ∀ g₁ ∈ G, ∀ g₂ ∈ G, g₁.1 = g₂.1 → g₁.2 = g₂.2) :
    ∃ f : H →* I, ∀ x, x ∈ G ↔ f x.1 = x.2 := by
  use
  { toFun := fun h ↦ (hf₁ h).choose.val.snd
    map_one' := hf _ (hf₁ 1).choose.2 1 (one_mem _) (hf₁ 1).choose_spec
    map_mul' := fun h₁ h₂ ↦ by
      have := calc (hf₁ (h₁ * h₂)).choose.val.fst
        _ = h₁ * h₂ := (hf₁ (h₁ * h₂)).choose_spec
        _ = (hf₁ h₁).choose.val.fst * (hf₁ h₂).choose.val.fst := by
          congr 1; exacts [(hf₁ h₁).choose_spec.symm, (hf₁ h₂).choose_spec.symm]
        _ = (((hf₁ h₁).choose * (hf₁ h₂).choose)).val.fst := by
          simp only [coe_subtype, comp_apply, coe_mul, Prod.fst_mul]
      simp only [← Prod.snd_mul]
      refine hf _ (hf₁ _).choose.2 _ ?_ this
      exact mul_mem (hf₁ h₁).choose.2 (hf₁ h₂).choose.2 }
  intro x
  simp only [MonoidHom.coe_mk, OneHom.coe_mk]
  refine ⟨fun hx ↦ hf _ (hf₁ _).choose.2 _ hx (hf₁ _).choose_spec, fun hx₂ ↦ ?_⟩
  exact (Prod.ext (hf₁ x.1).choose_spec hx₂).symm ▸ (hf₁ x.1).choose.2
```

I had a look at this, and I understand now why you were using morphisms from another monoid, rather than submonoids. (I got into a real mess trying to derive the morphism version from the submonoid version, while the implication the other way around is easy).

I have pushed a linear-maps version of the "line test" to your branch here.

> I had a look at this, and I understand now why you were using morphisms from another monoid, rather than submonoids. (I got into a real mess trying to derive the morphism version from the submonoid version, while the implication the other way around is easy).

Oh, interesting. I went for the hom version because it felt "right", but I hadn't actually tried to deduce it from the submonoid version.

I added the isomorphism version of the results for modules.

(I can't understand how anyone can bear working on PRs that touch very foundational files, you have to wait such an incredibly long time to find out if your changes break anything downstream.)

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#18870~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Have you considered doing this for plain functions first? And then the monoid version on top of that. And then the linear version on top of that...
Sure. I think the plain function basically already exists under various names, but we can add docstrings to that effect

Please do!

bors d+

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Done! Turns out the plain function versions didn't exist, so I added them

bors merge

source.title: feat: Decomposing a submodule of a product

nodes.body: What's the motivation for considering homomorphisms from an arbitrary `G`, rather than just inclusions of subgroups? The statement actually only depends on the image of `f` in `H \times I`, not on `G` and `f`.

FWIW, a submonoid version of your first lemma might look like
```lean
lemma Submonoid.eq_graph (G : Submonoid (H × I)) (hf₁ : Surjective (Prod.fst ∘ G.subtype))
    (hf : ∀ g₁ ∈ G, ∀ g₂ ∈ G, g₁.1 = g₂.1 → g₁.2 = g₂.2) :
    ∃ f : H →* I, ∀ x, x ∈ G ↔ f x.1 = x.2 := by
  use
  { toFun := fun h ↦ (hf₁ h).choose.val.snd
    map_one' := hf _ (hf₁ 1).choose.2 1 (one_mem _) (hf₁ 1).choose_spec
    map_mul' := fun h₁ h₂ ↦ by
      have := calc (hf₁ (h₁ * h₂)).choose.val.fst
        _ = h₁ * h₂ := (hf₁ (h₁ * h₂)).choose_spec
        _ = (hf₁ h₁).choose.val.fst * (hf₁ h₂).choose.val.fst := by
          congr 1; exacts [(hf₁ h₁).choose_spec.symm, (hf₁ h₂).choose_spec.symm]
        _ = (((hf₁ h₁).choose * (hf₁ h₂).choose)).val.fst := by
          simp only [coe_subtype, comp_apply, coe_mul, Prod.fst_mul]
      simp only [← Prod.snd_mul]
      refine hf _ (hf₁ _).choose.2 _ ?_ this
      exact mul_mem (hf₁ h₁).choose.2 (hf₁ h₂).choose.2 }
  intro x
  simp only [MonoidHom.coe_mk, OneHom.coe_mk]
  refine ⟨fun hx ↦ hf _ (hf₁ _).choose.2 _ hx (hf₁ _).choose_spec, fun hx₂ ↦ ?_⟩
  exact (Prod.ext (hf₁ x.1).choose_spec hx₂).symm ▸ (hf₁ x.1).choose.2
```
